image.altText: Lindsay Thomas stands in bush.

props.synopsis: Port Augusta is turning into a battleground for Labor and the Coalition's opposing solutions to reducing carbon emissions, with some threatening legal action if the Coalition wins government.

title.children: Port Augusta First Nations group considers legal battle over proposed nuclear power plant

image.altText: A sign in a window which says Networ Outage hope to open soon

props.synopsis: CrowdStrike became a household name on Friday for all the wrong reasons. Here's what we know about them.

title.children: How a group of tech 'rebels' triggered the world's biggest IT meltdown

image.altText: The CrowdStrike branding is seen on teh front of an office building

props.synopsis: Australia's peak body for cyber security executives says the federal government should consider a review of cyber security and software systems in the wake of the outages.

title.children: Microsoft says CrowdStrike outage affected more than 8 million computers

image.altText: Donald Trump speaks at a podium

props.synopsis: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump holds his first campaign event since the attempt on his life, telling a crowd of supporters he "took a bullet for democracy".

title.children: Trump says he 'took a bullet for democracy' in first campaign rally since assassination attempt

image.altText: The front of a hotel in Thailand.

props.synopsis: Investors meet at a luxury hotel in Bangkok to try to get their money back, but none leave alive and now Thai police and the FBI are investigating an apparent murder-suicide by cyanide poisoning.

title.children: A group of investors walked into a Thai hotel room to recover their money, but none came out alive

image.altText: Close up of sign saying Unley Oval

props.synopsis: "Misinformation" and community "division" — it sounds like the latest report about the upcoming American presidential election. In fact it's a sleepy suburb in Adelaide's inner-south where a proposal to build a fence has ignited online fury.

title.children: 'Storm in teacup' erupts over council proposal to return fencing to home of Double Blues

image.altText: Shop front with the sign 'Cignall' in black writing above the door

props.synopsis: Australia's tobacco excise is "well past its point of effectiveness", according to one expert, who says it's pushing smokers onto the black market, hurting retailers and taxpayers.

title.children: Tobacconists caught selling black market cigarettes are making so much money, fines are considered 'a cost of doing business'

image.altText: A man in a suit standing in front of a purple screen

props.synopsis: Green hydrogen might be more efficient than petrol but it doesn't rate against a battery-driven vehicle, and funding it is proving to be difficult with iron ore prices falling.

title.children: Why Andrew Forrest stepped back on green hydrogen

image.altText: a boy and a girl smile at camera in front of a swimming pool wearing South Australia jumpers

props.synopsis: Young swimmers in Kyle Chalmers' home town are drawing plenty of inspiration from the Olympic medallist as they dive in for training on cold winter mornings.

title.children: Port Lincoln kids gun for hometown hero Kyle Chalmers' records as Games excitement builds

image.altText: A pile of tablets with embossed numbers and letters sits on a dark surface

props.synopsis: SA Health is warning of the life-threatening dangers of a synthetic opioid after an Adelaide man almost died in hospital when he consumed a single street-purchased oxycodone pill last week.

title.children: 'This drug can kill you in a tablet': Warnings over potentially deadly synthetic opioid

image.altText: new south wales state emergency service workers remove a turned over trampoline after strong winds 200724

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology said the worst of the weather compared to the past two days was over, as winds continue to ease in south-eastern parts of the country throughout the afternoon and evening.

title.children: Severe weather easing across south-east Australia as SES teams work to restore power lines, remove fallen trees

image.altText: A newly married couple hold hands at their wedding.

props.synopsis: In a more diverse world, with a dizzying array of dating apps to introduce us to a wider pool of potential partners than our grandparents care to imagine, how much is our choice of romantic partner changing? Tell us your love stories.

title.children: I've noticed something odd about most couples. Psychologists and geneticists have noticed it too

image.altText: A medicine bottle with a tag warning the medicine may cause drowsiness

props.synopsis: Experts are worried about a proliferation of "single-issue" cannabis clinics opening in Australia, some of them willing to prescribe via telehealth consultations with few checks.

title.children: Doctors warn of significant increase in people hospitalised with psychosis after being prescribed medicinal cannabis

image.altText: Julie Critchley and her husband next to a Mockingbird sign

props.synopsis: A foster care program that links up parents to create an extended family-like environment has helped improve carer retention and created better placement stability for children — with the program's facilitator now looking to further expand the program across the country.

title.children: 'Blend like cousins': Mockingbird foster program mimics extended family

image.altText: An illustration of a briefcase with cash coming out. The whole image is glitching.

props.synopsis: From cryptocurrency to video games, criminals are turning to some surprising digital technologies to help launder money.

title.children: How do modern criminals launder money? Some are doing it by playing video games

image.altText: Close-up of Donald Trump's ear with a biege bandaid on top

props.synopsis: Donald Trump has held his first rally since the assassination attempt at his campaign event last weekend, with his newly minted running mate JD Vance joining him in Grand Rapids, Michigan.

title.children: Trump promises to 'fight, fight, fight' at first campaign rally since assassination attempt — as it happened

image.altText: A vapour trail in a sunset sky over the ocean, and silhouettes of palm trees.

props.synopsis: Five years after Starlink satellites started orbiting the Earth, Pacific Island countries are still weighing up its benefits despite calls to approve its services.

title.children: Elon Musk's Starlink satellites promise to connect the Pacific to the internet. So why are some countries trying to ban it?

image.altText: A woman holds pamphlets in her hand as she stands on the footpath. Behind her is a sign that says 'Babies lives matter'.

props.synopsis: At stake in the upcoming US election is something Americans once took for granted — and Donald Trump helped take away.

title.children: Lynn has been protesting outside abortion clinics for 51 years. She's 'definitely' voting for Trump

image.altText: SAS soldier overlooks valley in Afghanistan as Black Hawk helicopter flies past in 2012.

props.synopsis: The Australian government has laid out how it will compensate the families of people found to have been unlawfully killed or abused by Australian special forces in Afghanistan.

title.children: Defence takes 'significant step forward' to compensate for unlawful Afghanistan killings

image.altText: A paddock of dairy cows on rolling hills

props.synopsis: Seafood waste is being made into fertiliser and a cheese boiler plant runs on wood waste in the small New South Wales town. Could this be the future of sustainability?

title.children: The boss of Bega cheese heard the Netherlands wanted to become a circular economy. Now he wants it for his town

image.altText: Stills of video which played a role in the Australian's four month investigation

props.synopsis: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) discontinues its investigation into "white hands on black art" allegations at the APY Arts Centre Collective (APY CCC), saying it has found nothing to suggest consumer law has been breached.

title.children: ACCC finds no consumer law breached in 'white hands on black art' allegations

image.altText: A female crayfish stretches its claws and had  eggs under its tail like little red berries

props.synopsis: The species has been mostly absent from the South Australian stretch of the river for around 40 years. Now, the population is getting another boost.

title.children: Once extinct Murray crayfish on track to 'thrive again' in SA's River Murray

image.altText: Scientists open an octopus.

props.synopsis: School-age, university students and keen members of the public have gathered to observe a rare public dissection of a 140kg octopus squid found off South Australia's Eyre Peninsula.

title.children: 'Exceptionally rare' octopus squid dissected by researchers at SA university

image.altText: Thermal image of a concrete surface with a wire fence behind it.

props.synopsis: Some 34 years after operations closed at the North Cliff mining site in Dharawal National Park, vision given to the ABC shows methane gas leaking out into the atmosphere.

title.children: A gas '80 times more harmful than CO2' is seeping out of a Sydney mine not used in decades

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: Oh, you're back? Something to prove after last week's effort? Let's see what you've got.

title.children: Don’t be shy now. You think you know it all? Prove it. Let’s play … HARD!

image.altText: CFMEU generic

props.synopsis: The independent probe will look at ways to strength the response to allegations involving the CFMEU and remove individuals engaged in criminal practices.

title.children: Victorian review to strengthen ability to remove construction officials involved in criminal behaviour

image.altText: People watch as flames are seen in the distance, over the top of low buildings

props.synopsis: The Israeli strikes appeared to be the first on Yemeni soil since the Israel-Gaza war began in October, and they threaten to open a new front in the region as Israel battles proxies of Iran.

title.children: Israeli military says it has struck Houthi targets in Yemen in response to attacks

image.altText: Graves at Fromelles, France following the infamous battle of July 1916

props.synopsis: The remains of 70 Australian WWI soldiers found in a mass grave at Fromelles are still to be identified. On the anniversary of the bloody battle they died in, a volunteer organisation is asking for help and DNA to give them back their names.

title.children: DNA detective work could end the mystery of 70 unknown diggers killed in Fromelles horror

image.altText: Tadej Pogacar

props.synopsis: Jonas Vinegaard says he had hoped Tadej Pogacar would let him win the penultimate stage of the Tour de France — instead, the Slovenian created history.

title.children: Pogacar equals Tour de France record and shatters rival's spirits with another win in penultimate stage

image.altText: Nina Kennedy

props.synopsis: Nina Kennedy, Oliver Hoare, and Mackenzie Little win their events at the London Diamond League a week out from the start of Paris 2024.

title.children: Trio of Aussie athletes win their events at London Diamond League in ominous sign for rivals ahead of Paris Olympics

image.altText: A welcome to Canberra, Australia's capital sign with graffiti below reading "of weird rules".

props.synopsis: Newcomers to Canberra are often struck by the absence of front fences, which is the result of just one of the obscure rules in place in the nation's capital.

title.children: It's been 100 years since front fences were banned in Canberra — but that's not the only quirky ACT law

image.altText: Photographed from above, a woman in a sparkly pink top strokes her daughter's hair, who is burying her face into her neck.

props.synopsis: Tasmania is in the throes of a housing crisis, and women and children are particularly vulnerable, according to a recent report. Advocates are especially concerned for those experiencing family violence, calling housing a "key piece of the puzzle".

title.children: Caught in a violent relationship and a housing crisis, Cody's choice was 'either stay or be on the street'

image.altText: Prince George of Wales and Prince William hug each other in the box of a soccer stadium

props.synopsis: During the UEFA Euro final the whole world saw the warmth of Prince William and Prince George's relationship. In a family fractured with discord and burdened with ill-health, this was a tonic.

title.children: In a fractured royal family, Prince William and George's show of joy at the Euro final was a tonic

image.altText: Two men sit on a stone wall. One is a  double amputee, the other holds a white stick.

props.synopsis: Ben Pettingill, who is 98 per cent blind, needs someone by his side when he runs. With his mate Mike Rolls, the pair have found no shortage of people willing to run and chat about life.

title.children: These mates are affectionately known as 'Legless and Blind'. They use running to start tough conversations

image.altText: Heather Donahue in The Blair Witch Project

props.synopsis: The creative low-budget film gave rise to a new genre of found-footage nightmares — and the tradition continues today.

title.children: The Blair Witch Project at 25: How one film changed the horror genre as we know it
